column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.DemoNERRE|NamedentityTags
#T_RL=webanno.custom.DemoRE|NamedentityRelations|BT_webanno.custom.DemoNERRE
#Text=Polycrystalline samples of LaO0.5F0.5BiS2 were prepared using a HP synthesis
#Text=technique with a cubic-anvil-type 180 ton press.
#Text=The starting materials are La2S3
#Text=(99.9 %), Bi2O3 (99.99 %), BiF3 (99.9 %) and Bi2S3 powders and Bi (99.99 %) grains.
#Text=The Bi2S3 powder was prepared by reacting Bi and S (99.99 %) grains.
#Text=The mixture
#Text=with a nominal composition of LaO0.5F0.5BiS2 was well-mixed and pressed into a pellet.
#Text=The sample was sealed into a BN sample space and inserted into a HP cell.
#Text=The HP cell was pressed with a pressure of 2 GPa and heated with various
#Text=annealing temperatures and times.
#Text=The detailed annealing conditions are listed in
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=The temperature dependence of electrical resistivity below 300 K was
#Text=measured using the four-terminal method.
#Text=The DC magnetic susceptibility was
#Text=measured using a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID)
#Text=magnetometer after both zero-field cooling (ZFC) and field cooling (FC).
#Text=The Tconset in
#Text=the susceptibility measurement was estimated to be a temperature where the
#Text=susceptibility began to decrease.
#Text=The error of the Tconset in the phase diagram (Fig. 4)
#Text=was estimated by considering the real value of the susceptibility error at normal
#Text=conducting states around 15 K.
#Text=For Tcirr, the reliable estimation of error was quite
#Text=difficult due to drastic change of susceptibility around Tcirr.
#Text=Hence we did not plot in the
#Text=phase diagram.
#Text=The powder X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried
#Text=out using a Rigaku SmartLab powder diffractometer equipped with a CuKα1
#Text=monochrometer.
#Text=To compare XRD patterns of various samples precisely, the standard Si
#Text=powder was mixed with the samples, and used as the reference of the calibration of the
#Text=peak shift.
